reviews.review_msg: The course itself is not difficult to get an A in. That being said, Jessica seemed to get annoyed by small mistakes. If we mess formatting up, she picks on it. Larger mistakes were pointed out by her too, it felt like I was belittled by her. The course is very interesting, but I wouldn't take a course w/ her again.
The course is extremely easy but she does not know how to teach. She discusses basic things in the class and expects you to write the most perfect assignments.

I took EDUC322 online, and it appears my experience was very different from other commenters here. The class was an easy A: three 500 word papers, quizzes every module, and then a final project that you hand in a draft of first so you can get feedback. She provided a free textbook that she wrote herself. I found the content easy and interesting.
I trusted other students' compliments regarding her teaching. Now I regret it. This course has been the worst for me as a 4th year student.

DON'T TAKE this course with her, she is awful. She doesn't have clear rubric for assignments. She picks on silly things and deducts a huge percentage. Contents are easy but her marking makes you doubt your writing ability. If you ask for clear direction, she won't give helpful answers. Her feedback in one assignment isn't useful for the next one.

If you've taken any educational or developmental psych classes before, this class is a breeze -- almost no new concepts. I found that boring, but I guess an A is an A. Relies a LOT on group discussions (like, half the class time) and also includes a group presentation, so if you're shy, avoid. Classes almost always end about an hour early.

Jessica is a lovely professor who is passionate about teaching. The course content was extremely valuable to me and the grading criteria was clear. If you plan to take Educ 322 note that she pays close attention to the rubric/assignment outline when grading. Make sure you check your work to see if all the components are done properly.
